What to do when you receive an Evacuation Order

PreparedBC

Visit PreparedBC to get yourself, your loved ones and your home prepared for the hazards you may face, including wildfire.

Evacuation Stages

Understanding Flood Advisories

Evacuation Order

You are at risk. Leave the area immediately.

Evacuation Alert

Be ready to leave on short notice

Evacuation Rescind

All is currently safe and you can return home.

Get prepared for a wildfire

Develop a household plan

An emergency plan will help your household respond to a disaster. Knowing what to do will reduce anxiety and help you respond better and recover faster.

Build your grab-and-go bags

Having a grab-and-go bag means you'll be ready to leave on short notice. Each member of your household should have their own unique to their needs, including pets.

FireSmart your property

Creating a FireSmart property will dramatically increase the resistance of your home and property to damage caused by wildfire.

PreparedBC

Visit PreparedBC to get yourself, your loved ones and your home prepared for the hazards you may face, including wildfire.

item.title: Homepage
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Current emergencies

There are no active emergencies at this time

Definitions

Flood Warning Levels

Understanding Flood Advisory threat stages

Flood Warning

River levels have exceeded bankfull or will exceed bankfull imminently, and that flooding of areas adjacent to the rivers affected will result.

Flood Watch

River levels are rising and will approach or may exceed bankfull. Flooding of areas adjacent to affected rivers may occur.

High Streamflow Advisory

River levels are rising or expected to rise rapidly, but no major flooding is expected. Minor flooding in low-lying areas is possible.

Evacuation Stages

Understanding Flood Advisories

Evacuation Order

You are at risk. Leave the area immediately.

Evacuation Alert

Be ready to leave on short notice

Evacuation Rescind

All is currently safe and you can return home.

Public Safety Conditions across B.C.

Report an emergency

For police, fire, and medical emergencies call 9-1-1

Report an earthquake

Website: Earthquakes Canada

Report a wildfire

Cell Phone: *5555

Phone: 1-800-663-5555

Website: Report a wildfire

Report a chemical spill

Phone: 1-800-663-3456

Website: Report a spill

What to do if you receive a B.C. Emergency Alert?

During a life threatening emergency a BC Emergency Alert may be issued to radio, TV and cell phones:

Stop what you are doing

Read the alert & see if you are in the affected area

Follow all directions immediately

PreparedBC offers emergency preparedness resources for individuals, communities and organizations.

Are you prepared for these emergencies?

Flood

Wildfires

Earthquake

Tsunami

Extreme Heat

Avalanche

PreparedBC offers emergency preparedness resources for individuals, communities and organizations.

Learn about the hazards in your community

Make your emergency plan

Gather emergency supplies

Visit PreparedBC Facebook

Visit PreparedBC Twitter

Visit PreparedBC Instagram

Flood evacuee guidance

General emergency evacuee guidance information for the public. Always follow the instructions of your Local Authority or First Nation.

River Forecast Centre

Updates on current Flood Advisories in BC.

DriveBC

Latest travel and highway updates in BC. Find your regional DriveBC Twitter account.

Evacuation Stages

Understanding Flood Advisories

Evacuation Order

You are at risk. Leave the area immediately.

Evacuation Alert

Be ready to leave on short notice

Evacuation Rescind

All is currently safe and you can return home.

Get prepared for a flood

Get prepared

Floods are common in BC. Understand what to do before, during and after a major flood.

Develop a household plan

An emergency plan will help your household respond to a disaster. Knowing what to do will reduce anxiety and help you respond better and recover faster.

Put together an emergency kit

Gather your emergency supplies.

During severe flooding, you may need to shelter at home with an emergency kit or leave immediately with your grab-and-go bag.

Connect with your neighbours (PDF)

Prepared neighbourhoods are resilient neighbourhoods. When you're in it together, you'll respond better and recover faster from an emergency.

Get prepared for a flood

Develop a household plan

An emergency plan will help your household respond to a disaster. Knowing what to do will reduce anxiety and help you respond better and recover faster.

Put together an emergency kit

Pack your grab-and-go-bags:

During a flood, you may be required to evacuation on short notice. Pack a grab-and-go back so you have your essential items with you.

Connect with your neighbours (PDF)

Prepared neighbourhoods are resilient neighbourhoods. When you're in it together, you'll respond better and recover faster from an emergency.

item.title: Earthquake
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Preliminary Earthquake Parameters

Local Time

15:07:30 PDT

Magnitude

3.4

Latitude

53.65 North

UT Date & Time

  • 2022/09/21
  • 22:07:30 UT

Depth

5.00 km

Longitude

122.94 West

More details available from Natural Resources Canada

Recommended Actions

1

Remain calm

Stay calm and move carefully, checking for unstable objects and other hazards above and around you.

2

Check for damage and hazards

  • Put on sturdy shoes and protective clothing before checking for damage and hazards
  • If you smell gas or rotten eggs, leave the building immediately and call 9-1-1 or your gas company's emergency phone number

3

Listen to instructions

  • Follow local information on the web, social media, radio and TV
  • If further actions are required in your community, local officials will provide instruction

4

Report the earthquake

  • Do NOT call 9-1-1 to report the earthquake
  • If you felt the earthquake, report it at Earthquakes Canada

5

Aftershocks could occur:

  • When you feel shaking, drop, cover and hold on
  • Wait for the shaking to stop and count to 60 before getting up

Links & Resources

Natural Resources Canada

Earthquakes Canada provides information on earthquakes that occur in Canada including magnitude, location, time and felt reports.

U.S. Geological Survey (USGS)

USGS provides international information on earthquakes.

National Tsunami Warning Center (NTWC)

NTWC provides international information and alerts on earthquakes and potential tsunamis.

Preparing for earthquakes

Earthquakes can't be predicted. Take the following steps to stay safe:

Drop, cover and hold on

  • Drop to your hands and knees. If you're inside, stay inside â€“ don't run outdoors or to other rooms
  • Cover your head and neck with your arm and take shelter under a sturdy piece of furniture
  • Hold on to your shelter, covering your head and neck until the shaking stops

Prepare your home

Before an earthquake, you can help prevent injuries and damage by making some changes inside your home.

Build an emergency kit and grab-and-go bags

After an earthquake you may need to shelter at home with an emergency kit or you may need to leave quickly with a grab-and-go bag.

Research insurance options

Home insurance policies in B.C. cover earthquake damage and losses. Call your insurance representative to discuss your coverage or contact the Insurance Bureau of Canada at 1-844-227-5422.

item.title: Amber Alert
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Call 9-1-1 to report sightings. Do not approach.

Victim name: Phaivanh Correia-Chanthabouala

Enlarge

Enlarge

Age: 3

Gender: Male

Height: 2 ft 0 inch

Weight: 30 lbs

Hair Colour: Black

Eye Colour: Brown

Race: Asian

Important Descriptors:

3-years old, 2ft, black hair, wearing grey zip up, blue pants and red shoes.

Suspect name: Jenny Chanthabouala

Enlarge

Age: 30

Gender: Female

Height: 5 ft 2 inch

Weight: 106 lbs

Hair Colour: Black

Eye Colour: Brown

Race: Asian

Important Descriptors:

Asian female, tattoo sleeve right arm, long black dreadlock hair, black jacket, black toque, glasses, grey sweatpants, red/yellow/turquoise striped messenger bag, brown Ugg boots.

Vehicle: Name

Enlarge

Year: 2008

Colour: Dark Grey

Make: Dodge

Model: Journey

License number: 000000

Province: B.C.

Type: ___

Style: ___

Vehicle is: Stolen

Important Descriptors:

The suspect's vehicle is a black Dodge Journey with tinted windows and a dent on the driver's side door. It has a license plate number of ABC123 and was last seen heading eastbound on Main Street.

Recommended Actions

1

When an Amber Alert is issued

If you receive an Amber Alert, watch for the child, suspect, and/or vehicle described in the alert.

2

DO NOT approach the victim or suspect

  • Do not attempt to apprehend the child/suspect yourself.
  • Do not attempt to stop the vehicle.

3

Report any sightings

  • Immediately report any sightings to the police by calling 9-1-1.
  • Provide the location and a description of the victim, suspect, and/or vehicle.

For more information, visit the BC RCMP Amber Alert Program website.

Links & Resources

BC RCMP News Room

For updates, follow @BCRMP on Twitter or visit the BC RCMP News Room.

BC Emergency Alert

This Amber Alert was broadcast on radio, TV, and to connect mobile devices.

item.title: Emergency Alert
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Current BC Emergency Alert

Evacuation order issued by the Peace River Regional District

May 10, 2023 at 2:00 pm

An Evacuation Order and an Emergency Alert has been issued by the Peace River Regional District for the Community of Kelly Lake, in Electoral Area D, due to wildfire. Impacted residents should evacuate the area immediately.

BC Emergency Alert Message

Evacuation Order issued by the Peace River Regional District, with support from EMBC. Immediately evacuate if you are in the evacuation area or directed to do so. The Bearhole Lake Wildfire is creating significant risk to life safety. Evacuate via Hwy 671 to Range Rd 131, North to Hwy 43 OR Hwy 52 East, North to BC Hwy 2. If you are trapped and unable to evacuate call 911 and report your location ASAP. For more information go to the PRRD website or social media. Evacuation area â€“ The community of Kelly Lake, 5km North of Kelly Lake, 5km South of Kelly Lake, 4km West of the Alberta border.

item.title: Heat
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Active Heat Warnings in British Columbia

Northeast

  • Northern Interior
  • Central Interior, including Chilcotin, Cariboos
  • Prince George,
  • North Thompson,
  • North Columbia,
  • BC Peace, Bulkley Valley
  • The Lakes
  • Fort Nelson

Northwest

  • Central and Northern Coast (inland and coastal regions)
  • Northern Vancouver Island
  • Northwestern BC

Southeast

  • Central and Northern Coast (inland and coastal regions)
  • Northern Vancouver Island
  • Northwestern BC

Southwest

  • Western Metro Vancouver including the North Shore
  • City of Vancouver and Richmond
  • Howe Sound
  • Whistler
  • Sunshine Coast
  • Vancouver Island (except northern sections)

Southwest inland

  • Eastern Metro Vancouver including Coquitlam and Surrey
  • Fraser Valley

Heat Warning Map

Cooling Centres

Cooling centres

In response to Heat Warnings, cooling centres may be opened for the public at the discretion of local governments and First Nations in affected areas.

Visit your First Nation or local government website for cooling centres in your area.

Contact a healthcare provider or call HealthLinkBC at 8-1-1 if you think you are experiencing heat-related symptoms. Mild to moderate heat illness can quickly become severe. Call 9-1-1 in case of medical emergency.

Heat is more dangerous to young children and the elderly. If you are safe and able to, check on your neighbours and elders and look for signs of heat-related illness.

British Columbia - Vancouver Island

Cowichan Tribes

Nanaimo Woodgrove Center

YMCA Duncan

British Columbia - Southwest

Richmond Community Hall

Whistler Village Stadium

Sunshine Coast Legion

Heat Safety and Preparedness

Preparing for heat

BC Centre for Disease Control

PreparedBC

Extreme Heat Guide (PDF, 9.4 MB)

Health Authorities - Heat response information

Fraser Health

Interior Health

First Nations Health Authority

Island Health

Northern Health

Vancouver Coastal Health

Definitions

Heat Warning

Daytime and overnight temperatures are higher than usual, but they are not getting hotter every day. Take the usual steps to stay cool.

Extreme Heat Emergency

Daytime and overnight temperatures are higher than usual and are getting hotter every day. Activate your emergency plan for heat.
